articles.title: JULY 1986
articles.summary: This document outlines the schedule of events for July and August 1986, primarily for the SJAA (San Jose Astronomical Association). It includes multiple astronomical observation field expeditions to various state parks, an annual picnic, board meetings, introductory astronomy classes, and an indoor star party. A highlight for August is a general meeting featuring a Space Shuttle Astronaut and an observatory dedication at Fremont Peak State Park.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: The SJAA will host its annual picnic on July 12th at Grant Ranch County Park, providing burgers and buns while members bring other items. Concurrently, the F.P.O.A.'s 30-inch telescope observatory is under rapid construction, with walls and floor complete as of June 12th, aiming for an August 20th completion and dedication date, pending final work by Kevin Medlock on the telescope's computer controls and other installations.

articles.title: YOSEMITE TRIP -- GLACIER POINT STAR PARTY
articles.summary: Reservations for the Glacier Point Star Party at Yosemite quickly filled up, with 30 spots confirmed for the group camp area. Attendees who placed reservations should have received a confirmation letter outlining event guidelines and are advised to contact the organizer if they haven't. Organizers anticipate a large number of visitors on both Friday and Saturday nights due to the coinciding July 4th weekend.

articles.title: MEMBERSHIP RENEWALS
articles.summary: The Epheneris newsletter issues a final reminder for members to submit their subscription or membership renewals to Jack Peterson, emphasizing the busy period for the treasurer and urging early submission. Members who have already renewed are advised to disregard any 'LAST CHANCE TO RENEW' stamps. The document also includes 'Astro Ads' featuring a Celestron Super C8 telescope and a Celestron 5.5-inch f/1.55 Schmidt Camera for sale.

articles.title: BY: JAY REYNOLDS FREEMAN
articles.summary: This article advocates for science fiction as an engaging and educational alternative to traditional texts for learning about astronomy and scientific concepts. It recommends numerous authors and their works, including Robert Forward, Larry Niven, Hal Clement, David Brin, Robert A. Heinlein, and Arthur C. Clarke, highlighting their ability to weave plausible astronomical themes, advanced engineering, and alien biologies into compelling narratives. The author encourages readers to explore both contemporary and classic SF literature for its entertainment value and scientific intrigue.

articles.title: GREAT RED SPOT
articles.summary: The author successfully observed Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) after 183 days, noting its appearance 19 minutes earlier than predicted, with good seeing revealing a yellowish spot pushing into the South Equatorial Belt. The article discusses the GRS's varied historical visibility, from its brick-red appearance in the early 70s to times when it was invisible. It also touches upon the spot's erratic motion, which prevents long-term predictions, and its historical discovery credited to Cassini in 1665.

articles.title: Great Red Spot on Meridian PDT
articles.summary: This document provides a detailed schedule of predicted times for observing Jupiter's Great Red Spot (GRS) on the central meridian in PDT during July and early August. It offers practical advice for amateur astronomers, including recommended observing conditions, magnifications, and potential use of filters to enhance visibility. The article encourages observers to share their results, particularly those using smaller instruments or experimenting with observing aids.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article discusses the final observations of Comet Halley fading in July 1986 and introduces two new periodic comets discovered in May of that year. Periodic Comet Singer-Brewster (1986d) was found by a professional astronomer and is a short-period object returning in 6.1 years. The author, Don Machholz, an amateur astronomer, also discovered Periodic Comet Machholz (1986e).

articles.title: WHAT GOES AROUND COMES AROUND-HALLEY
articles.summary: This article discusses the diminishing visibility of Halley's Comet as it recedes from Earth and the Sun, noting it will soon be obscured by the sun for northern observers and become significantly fainter by mid-October. It provides specific dates for visibility challenges, mentions the comet has been brighter than predicted, and includes a detailed table of its positions, magnitude, and distances for late June and July.

articles.title: THE DISCOVERY OF PERIODIC COMET MACHHOLZ 1986e BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz recounts the conditions and preparations on the night of May 12, 1986, when he hunted for new comets despite hazy skies from his observing site on Loma Prieta. Using his homemade 5-inch binoculars, he proceeded with his planned observation session, which ultimately led to the discovery of Periodic Comet Machholz 1986e.

articles.title: Discovery of Comet Machholz
articles.summary: The article recounts the author's journey into comet hunting, detailing the construction of a unique pair of large binoculars in 1983 and their use alongside a 10-inch reflector. It describes a specific comet hunting session on May 12, 1986, where a fuzzy object was observed, and reflects on the author's extensive dedication to the hobby, which led to the discovery of two comets, Comet Machholz 1978L and 1985e, after thousands of hours of searching.

articles.title: Comet Discovery
articles.summary: The article recounts the author's personal discovery of a new comet, later named "Comet Machholz" (1988e). The discovery involved visual confirmation of its movement against background stars, followed by reporting to the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory and subsequent confirmations by other astronomers. Notably, the comet was found to have a rare short-period elliptical orbit of 5.4 years, characterized by a highly tilted path and an unusually close perihelion to the sun.

articles.title: ROGERS COMMISSION REPORT ON SHUTTLE DISASTER RELEASED
articles.summary: The article reports on the release of the Rogers Commission Report concerning the Space Shuttle Challenger disaster, which attributed the accident to solid rocket booster seals and NASA's management practices. The report detailed multiple factors contributing to the seal failure and recommended a complete redesign of the solid rocket boosters. President Reagan has mandated NASA to implement all of the commission's recommendations.

articles.title: ARIANE LAUNCH FAILURE
articles.summary: The launch of an Intelsat communications satellite failed on May 30th when the third stage of its Ariane booster did not ignite. This incident marks the fourth failure in 18 Ariane launches, with three of these failures specifically linked to the cryogenic third stage.

articles.title: DELTA, TITAN, ATLAS
articles.summary: Investigations continue into the electrical failure of the May 3rd Delta launch and the April 18th Titan failure, with parts of the Titan reassembled but the specific failure mode still unidentified. Meanwhile, an Atlas-Centaur is scheduled to launch a Navy Fleet Sat Com satellite on August 28th.

articles.title: SOVIETS PRACTICE SPACE CONSTRUCTION TECHNIQUES
articles.summary: Soviet cosmonauts conducted spacewalks from the Salyut 7 space station on May 28th and 30th to practice deploying a 15-meter-long truss. These activities were part of ongoing experiments in constructing large space structures, mirroring similar efforts by the US in late 1985.

articles.title: CONFIGURATION OF SPACE STATION DEFINED
articles.summary: The selected configuration for the space station is a dual-keel arrangement, featuring a 5-meter square truss structure and four pressurized modules from the U.S., Europe, and Japan. It will employ a hybrid power system combining solar arrays and solar dynamic power, hydrazine propulsion, and a 400 cycle a.c. distribution system. The station is designed to accommodate a crew of 6-8 astronauts and will include four free-flying platforms, with a scheduled completion for 1994.

articles.title: NATIONAL COMMISSION ON SPACE SETS 21ST CENTURY GOALS
articles.summary: The Presidential National Commission on Space presented its report, "Pioneering the Space Frontier, Our Next 50 Years in Space," to the White House in May. The report outlines ambitious 21st-century goals, including the establishment of a permanent settlement on the Moon by 2017 and a permanent settlement on Mars by 2027.

articles.title: LETTER TO THE EDITOR
articles.summary: This letter to the editor suggests that observers should match the exit pupil of their binoculars to the diameter of their own fully dilated pupil to maximize light grasp efficiency. It notes that pupil diameter often decreases with age, making binoculars like 7x35 more suitable and cost-effective than 7x50 for middle-aged users whose pupils may only dilate to 5mm, despite 7x50s offering more light potential for younger observers.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings and "Indoor Star Parties" at the Los Gatos Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California, on the 4th Saturday of each month. These gatherings offer a friendly atmosphere for members to share various astronomical interests, including astrophotography, deep-sky observation, and telescope making. The article provides directions and meeting times for these events.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: Monthly "INDOOR STAR PARTIES" are informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomy enthusiasts, including both members and non-members, to socialize and share their common interest. Attendees are encouraged to bring telescopes and accessories, with activities often including viewing astrophotography and ongoing star party events. These sessions also host SJAA meetings and an introductory astronomy workshop.

articles.title: HENRY COE STATE PARK
articles.summary: This document provides detailed directions to Henry Coe State Park, specifically to an astronomical observing site utilized by the SJAA (San Jose Astronomical Association). It includes navigational landmarks, instructions for a locked gate with a club combination (4565), and advice for parking and site setup, particularly for arrivals after dark.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: This article provides detailed directions to Fremont Peak State Park, a popular astronomical observing site for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). Located 3000 ft above sea level, Coulter Camp within the park is a regular gathering spot for astronomical activities every clear new moon weekend, often drawing 20 to 40 telescopes. The document also includes information about EPHEMERIS, the SJAA's monthly publication, and lists the association's officers and board of directors.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines various membership options, including 'Membership Only', 'Membership/S&T' (likely Sky & Telescope magazine), and 'Junior (Under 18)', along with their respective fees. The form provides fields for applicant details and instructions for submission via mail or in person.

articles.title: Questionnaire (optional)
articles.summary: This document is an optional questionnaire designed to gather information from individuals about their astronomical interests, whether they own a telescope, and if they have expertise in any specific area of astronomy. It appears to be part of a communication from an organization, likely an astronomy club, based on the return address details and 'NEWS MATERIAL' stamp.
